div.p: In which caſe the Infinitive may ſometimes (viz. if the former verb be a verb of motion) be varied by a Gerund in di, or dum: as, Eo viſendi cauſâ, or Ad viſendum: Sometimes by Ut, and a Subjunctive mood: as, Eo ut viſam: Sometimes by the firſt Supine, or by a Participle in rus, as Eo viſum, or viſurus, &c. Vide Chap. 44. Rule 3.
¶ Niſi is noctem ſibi ad deliberandum poſtulâſſet, Cic. ad Quir. poſt Redit. Pater huc me miſit ad vos oratum—Plaut. Amph. Prol.
11. (For) with all, all that, all this, &c. ſignifying though, XI. although, albeit, nevertheleſs, or notwithſtanding, is made by etſi, quanquam, quamvis, nihilominus, etiamſi, licet: as

cell.hi: I will go, for all [i. e. though] I have been already oft deceived of my hope.

row.cell: Ibo, etſi hercle ſaepe jam me ſpes haec fruſtrata eſt.

cell.hi: I can bear that too, for all [i. e. although] it is iniurious.

row.cell: Id quoque poſſum ferre, quanquam in jurium eſt.

cell.hi: I will do it yet for all this [i. e. nevertheleſs.]

row.cell: Nihilominus ego hoc faciam tamen.

cell.hi:
For all [i. e. notwithſtan •
ing] I gave you notice.

row.cell: Licèt tibi ſignificâram tamen.

cell.hi: I will not truſt you, for all that you ſwear, [or for all your ſwearing.]

row.cell: Etiamſi juraveris [or tibi vel jurato] fidem non habeo.

div.p: ¶ Tametſi majores, [For all you are my elder ſiſter,] Plaut. Stich. Act. 1. Sc. 1. Quanquam, [For all that] Terentianus ille Chremes, Humani nihil à ſe alienum putat, Cic. 1. Off. 12. Etiamſi ille his non eget, tamen ei potiſſimum inſerviunt, Cic. 1. Off. 19. Nihilominus, ut ipſi luceat, cùm accenderit, E • n. Ap. Cic. 1. Off. 20.
12. (For) after as, ſignifying of, as to, or concerning, is made XII by de, or quod ad: for example,

cell.hi: As for other matters, whatever ſhall be decreed, I will write to you.

row.cell: De caeteris rebus, quicquid erit actum ſcribam ad te, Cic 1. Fam. 2. Ep.

cell.hi: As for the money—

row.cell: Quod ad argentum attinet [or pertinet.]

div.p: ¶ De pace, ſentio ſimulationem eſſe apertam. Cic. ap. Turſel. c. 47. Obſ. 11. De paupertate, ſecurus ſum, Curt. 4. De Alemenâ, ut rem teneatìs, rectiùs, utrinque gravida eſt—Plaut. Amph. Prol. verſ. 109. Quod ad popularem rationem attinet—Cic. 1. Fam. 2. Ep. Quod ad nominationum analogiam pertinet, Varro ap. Steuich. l. 1. p. 345. Quatenus de religione dicebat, Bibulo aſſenſum eſt, Cic. 1. Fam. 2. Ep. Conſule Parei Commentarios de Partic. L. L. p. 605. Item, pag. 112. Item, Turſelini de Partic. cap. 167. Obſ 4. 4.
13. (For) Importing leave to do a thing, or when it may be XIII varied by theſe words, by reaſon, or becauſe of, is made by per: as

cell.hi: For me you may even ſleep, till you ſno • t again.

row.cell: Per me vel ſtertas licet.

cell.hi: Nor indeed could ſhe for [or by reaſon of] her age.

row.cell:
Ne
que per aetatem etiam poterat Ter. Eun.

div.p:
¶ Si eſſet licitum per nautas, Cic. 5. F. Ep. 4. Per aurium judicium licet, Cic. Or. Parere jamdiu haec per annos non poteſt, Ter. Ad. Cùm per aetatem potuiſſet, Val. Max. 3. 1. Per hanc tibi coenam incoenato Gelaſime eſſe hodie licet, Plaut. Stich. A. 4. Sc. 2. Suum cuique per me uti atque frui licet, Cato apud Gell. 13. 22. Cùm per valetudinem
poſſes, Cic. Fam. 7. Ep. 1. Vide Pareum de Partic L. L. p. 624, 625. & Turſel. de Partic. c. 139. Obſ. 8.
14. (For) Implying defence, or favour, may be rendred by à XIV pro, or ſecundum: as

cell.hi: He ſtood for the Smate.

row.cell: A Senatu ſtetit.

cell.hi: Apollo ſtood for Croy.

row.cell: Pro Trojâ ſtabat Apollo.

cell.hi: He ſpake much for [i. e. in favour of] our ſide.

row.cell: Multa ſecundum cauſam noſtram diſputavit, Cic. apud Danes, lib. 1. c. 31.

div.p: ¶ Vide nè hoc totum Scaevola ſit à me [i. e. pro me] Cic. 1. de Orat. Turſ. c. 1. obſ. 6. Ad dominam pro te verba tremente tuli, Ovid. Am. 1. 6. Pro patriâ cernit cum hoſtibus, Plaut. Amph. arg. 1. Secundum nos judicari volumus, Cic. Turſel. cap. 184. Obſ. 5. Pro me Conſules, ut referrent efflagitati ſunt, Cic. ad Quir. Decertare pro meâ ſalute nolui, Cic. ib. Nemo contra perditos cives à Senatu, & à bonorum virorum cauſâ ſterit conſtantiùs, Cic. de Cl. Orat. apud Pareum de Partic. L. L. p. 585. Commune eſt, quod nihilo magis ab adverſariis quàm à nobis facit, Id. apud eundem, ib.
15. (For) Som • times is part of the ſignification of the foregoing XV word: as

cell.hi: I have ſought for him all the Town over.

row.cell:
Per totum uſ
que oppidum quaeſivi eum.

cell.hi: I look for gueſts.

row.cell: Opperior convivas.

div.p: ¶ Una Elephantis pluribus ſufficit, Sen. Ep. 60.

cell.hi: He is beholden to you for his learning.

row.cell: Eruditionem ſuam tibi acceptam fert.

div.p: ¶ Qui mihi vitam ſuam referret acceptam, Cic. Philip. 2.

cell.hi: I thank you for writing to me.

row.cell: Ago tibi gratias de literis tuis.

cell.hi: I dare not for angring him.

row.cell: Non auſim, nè illum commoverem.

cell.hi: I would, but for hurting him.

row.cell: Vellem lubens, niſi foret ei damno.

cell.hi: It is for your good.

row.cell: In rem tuam
eſt.
E re tuâ

div.p: ¶ Si in rem eſt utrique—Sen. And. A. 3. Sc. 3. Quae maximè in rem voſtram communem ſient, Plaut. Amph. Prol.

cell.hi: Good for an ague.

row.cell: Efficax
febri curandae.
ad curandam febrem.

div.p: ¶ Utile eſt ad firmitudinem vocis, Cic. ad Heren. lib. 3.

cell.hi: It is moſt fit for your age.

row.cell: Aetati tuae aptiſſimum eſt, Cic. 1. Off.

cell.hi: It is a ſhame for you to ſtay for it.

row.cell: Hoc te expectars tibi turpe eſt, Cic.

div.p: ¶ Quod ipſi fuerit honeſtiſſimum dicere., Cic.

cell.hi: For the nonce.

row.cell: De induſtiâ
Datâ [deditâ] operâ.

cell.hi: I know it for a certain.

row.cell: Mihi eſt exploratiſſimum.

div.p: ¶ Cùm mihi eſſet exploratiſſimum, Cic. ad Quir. Nos quidem pro certo habebamus, Cic. Att. 7. 12.

cell.hi: For all that he could ſay or do.

row.cell: Quantumcunque conatus eſt

cell.hi: What cauſe is there for you to deſpatr?

row.cell: Quid eſt, quare deſperes? Sen. Ep. 44.

cell.hi: He hath paid for his folly.

row.cell: Dedit poenas vecordiae, Flor. 3. 7.

cell.hi: For the preſent.

row.cell: In praeſentiâ

div.p: ¶ De utrâque re ſimul erit in praeſentiâ dictum, Cic. ad Heren. 3.
But for, Chap. 13. Rule 2.
For the moſt part, Chap. 23. Phr. Append.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of the Particle From.
div.p: 1. FRom) before a Noun or Name of Place, is ſigne of an I. Ablative caſe, moſt uſually without, yet ſometimes with a Prepoſition: as

cell.hi: He goes from Capua to Rome.

row.cell: Capuâ Romam petit, Hor. 1. I. 7. Ep.

cell.hi: He went from Brunduſ • um.

row.cell: Diſceſſit Brunduſio [or à Brunduſio] Cic. Farnab. Gr. p. 86.

cell.hi: He is newly gone from home

row.cell: Nuper exiit domo.

div.p: ¶ Multi principes civitatis Româ profugerunt, Cic. Cat. 1. A me cum Philone Peſſinunte diſceſſit, Cic. 2. Fam. 12. Ep. Ambraciâ veniunt huc legati publicè, Plaut. Stich. A. 3. Sc. 2. Domo dudum huc accerſita ſum, Plaut. Video rure redeuntem ſenem, Ter. Eun. A Brunduſio nulla adhuc fama venerat, Cic. ad Att. l. 9. Ep. 3. Vide Danes Paralip. l. 3. c. 13. Si quae forte navis ex Aſiâ venerit, Plaut. Stich. A. 1. Sc. 2. Su • it humo pigrè, Ovid. Met. li. 2. verſ. 773.
2. (From) before the Engliſh of the Participle of the preſent II. tenſe, is made by à or ab, with a Gerund in do: as

cell.hi: Idle boyes are ſoon diſcouraged from learning.

row.cell: Ignavi à diſcendo citò deterrentur.

div.p: And if a Verb of hindring or with-holding go before, it may alſo be rendered by nè, or quò minus, with a Subjunctive mood: as

cell.hi: Thou haſt kept me from ſhedding of blood.

row.cell: Continuiſti me nè in irem caedes.

cell.hi: What keeps you from comming?

row.cell: Quid impedit quò minùs venias?

div.p:
¶ Dadas iis literas, per quas mecum agebas, nè eos impedirem, quò minùs ante hyemem aedificarent, Cic. 3. Ep. 7. Abs te peto, ut mei exiſtimes,
humanitate eſſe prohibitum, ne contra amici exiſtimationem venirem, Cic. Att. l. 1. Ep. 1. Si te infirmitas valetudinis tuae tenuit, quò minùs ad ludos venires—Cic. Fam. l. 7. Ep. 1. Per eos, nè cauſam diceret •• eripuit, Caſ. de bell. Gall. l. 1. Bene meritos quin colas, nec exorarifas eſt, neque—Cic. ad Quir. Virgil. tamen habet, [Georg. 4. v. 10.] nam pabula venti Ferre domum prohibent.
3. (From) after verbs of taking away, is ſigne either of a III. Dative, or Ablative with a Prepoſition: as

cell.hi: To take away ones life from him.

row.cell: Eripere alicui [or ab aliquo] vitam.

div.p:
¶ Adimam tibi nam
que figuram, Ovid. Met. 2. 475. Quid ſi praeripiat flavae Venus arma Minervae? Ovid. Am. 1. 1. Conſcia de tergo pallia deme tuo, Id. ib. Eleg. 4. Id totum eripere vobis conatus eſt, Cic. de Leg. Agr.
4. (From) in other ſignifications, is either included in the IV. Latine of the foregoing verb, or made by à, ab, è, ex, or de: as

cell.hi: Hidden vertue does but little differ from buried ſloth.

row.cell: Paulum ſepultae diſtat inertiae celata virtus, Hor. 4. l. Od. 9.

cell.hi: He received a Letter from Peter.

row.cell: Accepit literas à Petro.

cell.hi: The Emperour is a great way off from the City.

row.cell: Procul abeſt ab urbe Imperator.

cell.hi: To caſt down from on high.

row.cell: E ſublimi jacere, Plin.

cell.hi: I ſpeak from my heart.

row.cell: Ex animo dico.

cell.hi: He goes from what he ſaid.

row.cell: De ſententiâ decedit.

div.p: ¶ Viri noſtri domo, ut abierunt hic tertius annus, Plaut. Stich. Act. 1. Sc. 1. Cui cognomon ſuperbo ex moribus datum, Flor. 1. 7. I have heard all from the beginning. A principio audivi omnia, Ter. De ceſpite virgo ſe levat, Ovid. Genitus alto de corde Petitos edidit, Ovid. Met. 2. 624. Ex eo tempore, Cic. Noſque ab his abducere vult, Plaut. Stich. Act. 1. Sc. 1.

cell.hi: Not far from hence.

row.cell: Haud procul hinc, Ovid.

div.p: ¶ Hinc me depellite, ut Curt. l. 4 •

cell.hi: He went from thence.

row.cell: Indè abiit, Ter.

div.p: ¶ Inde expelli, unde invitus recedas, Sen. Ep. 54.

cell.hi: From our very childhood.

row.cell: Jam inde à puero, Ter.

cell.hi: He was ſo far from doing violence, that—

row.cell: Adeò ipſe non violavit, ut—

cell.hi: So far is my Oration from being weakened, that.

row.cell: Tantum abeſt, ut enervetur oratio, ut—

cell.hi: I have uſed him not to hide ought from me.

row.cell: Nequid me celet, eum conſueſeci.

div.p: ¶ Neque ego te celabo, neque tu me celâſſes, quod ſcies, Plaut. Stich. Act. 1. Sc. 2.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of the Particles His, Of his, Her, Their, Its, &c.
div.p:
1. HIs, Of his, Her, Their, Its) before I. How to rend ••
own, ſee Chap. 3 • Note 2. own, either expreſſed or underſtood, are made by ſuus: as

cell.hi: He paid the money with his own hand.

row.cell: Argentum ipſe mihi adnumeravit ſuâ manu, Plaut.

cell.hi: He muſt needs be a fool who ſoever is aſhamed of his own kindred.

row.cell: Quemcunque ſuae? origin •• poenitet, eum oportet, 〈◊〉 ineptum, Scal. de Cauſ. Li •• Lat. l. 6. cap. 130.

cell.hi: She has been ſo long without her huſband.

row.cell: Tandiu viro ſuo caruit, Pla •• Stich. Act. 1. Sc. 1.

cell.hi: They do not do their duty.

row.cell: Illi ſuum officium non colunt Plaut.

cell.hi: Of its own nature.

row.cell: Suopte ingenio.

div.p: ¶ Quondamque ſuis erravit in agris, Ovid. Met. Sponte ſuâ, Ovid. Met. 8. Suum omnes nationes tuentur morem, Scal. de Ling. Lat. li. 6. cap. 130. Suus omnibus Aſiaticis dicendi mos eſt, Scal. ib. Quid dulcius hominum generi à naturâ datum eſt, quam ſui cuique liberi? Cic. ad Quir. Res familiaris ſua quemque delectat, Cic. ib. Nunquam nimis curare poſſunt parentem ſuum ſiliae, Plaut. Stich. Suam claſſem attentatam magno cum ſuo periculo penè ſenſit, Cic. ad Quir.
(His, Of his, Her, Their, Its) Without own, are made moſt uſually by the Genitive Caſe of ſome of theſe Pronouns ille, ipſe, is, iſte? as

cell.hi: She hath what was his.

row.cell: Quae illius fuerunt poſſidet, Ter. And.

cell.hi: This treachery of his.

row.cell: Haec ejus perſidia.

cell.hi: Here were her armes.

row.cell: Hic illius arma—Virg. Aen. 1.

cell.hi: I did not ſo much regard my own buſineſſe as their play.

row.cell: Poſtpoſui tamen illorum mea ſerio ludo, Virg. Eclog. 7.

div.p: ¶ Propter eorum excellens ingenium, Cic. ad Quir. Collegâ ejus clementiſſimo primò non adverſante, Cic. ad Quir. Illius aram ſaepe tener noſtris ab ovilibus imbuet agnus, Virg. Ecl. 1. Adventus ipſius ad te ſatìs cum commendabit, Cic. 12. Ep. 6.
2. (Himſelf, Her ſelf, Themſelves, It ſelf) In the nominative II. Caſe are made by is, or ipſe: as

cell.hi: And indeed it is he himſelf.

row.cell: Et certè is eſt.

cell.hi: Iupiter himſelf is my father.

row.cell: Pater eſt mihi Jupiter ipſe, Ovid. Met. 2.

cell.hi: Since the Common wealth it ſelf hatk brought me back into the City—

row.cell: Quoniam me in civitarem reſpublica ipſa reduxit, Cic. ad Quir.

div.p:
¶ Denique ipſe ad extremum pro meâ vos ſalute non rogavit ſolùm, verùm etiam obſecravit, Cic. ad Quir. Quibus ipſe regna dederat
ad eos inops ſupplexque venit, Cic. ad Quir. Nunc ipſe Bruttius Romae mecum eſt, Cic. 13. F. 38. Ep. Aequitas enim lucet ipſa per ſe, Cic. 1. Offic. 12.
(Himſelf, Herſelf, Themſelves, Itſelf) In the Oblique Caſes, moſt uſually made by ſui, ſibi, ſe; as

cell.hi: Not ſo much to ſave themſelves.

row.cell: Non tam ſui conſervandi cauſâ, Cic.

cell.hi: He ſets too much by himſelf.

row.cell: Nimium tribuit ſibi [or admiratur ſe.]

cell.hi: Fannius killed himſelf.

row.cell: Se Fannius ipſe peremit, Ma • t.

div.p: ¶ Eorum eſt haec quaerela, qui ſibi chari ſunt, ſeſeque diligunt, Cic. 5. de Fin. Cùm privati ſe parietum praeſidio, non legum tuerentur, Cic. ad Quir. Neceſſe eſt enim ſibi nimium tribuat, qui ſe nemini comparat, Quintil. Inſt. 1. 2.
Note 1. The Reciproque ſuus is ſometimes * uſed for a Relative: as

cell.hi: I took the Pidgeon in her neſt.

row.cell: Cepi columbam in nido ſuo [for ejus or ipſius.]

div.p: ¶ Cic. * pro Sextio, Qui autem ità ſe gerebant, ut ſua [pro ipſorum] conſilia optimo cuique probarentur, hi optimates habebantur, Caeſar. 1. bell. Gall. Helvetii Allobrogibus ſeſe perſuaſueros exiſtimabant, ut per ſuos [pro ipſorum, vel eorum] ſines eos ire paterentur, Cato in Re Ruſticâ. Vinea, ſi macra erit, ſarmenta ſua [pro ejus] concidito, & ibidem inarato, Cic. 2. in Verr. Ut non modo in auribus veſtris, ſed in oculis omnium ſua [pro ejus vel ipſius] furta, atque flagitia deſixurus ſim, Ovid. 1. Epiſt. Reſpice Laerten, ut jam ſua lumiha condas [ubi ſua dixit, pro ejus vel ipſius.] Sed haec, ut inquit Daneſius, [3 lib. Paralip. cap. 17.] in exemplum non temerè trahenda ſunt: quippe quae malo, uti eſt Farnabio viſum [Syſtem. Gram. pag. 53.] exemplo ſiant. Ali • s tamen haud infimi ſubſellii Grammaticis ſuperiorum Latinae Linguae principium authoritate fret • s, exemplo nixis, contrarium placet. Videantur, Scalig. de Cauſ. Ling. Latinae lib. 6. cap. 130. Auguſt. Saturn. Mercur. Major. li. 5. cap. 12. Hawkinſii Syntax. Not. 37.
Note 2. A Relarive is ſometimes uſed for a Reciproque: as

cell.hi: Grammarians are at variance among themſelves.

row.cell: Grammaticis inter ipſos [for inter ſe] pugna eſt, Quint. li. 8. cap. 6.

cell.hi: The other became ſnrety for his appearance, ſo as that if he returned not, himſelf ſhould di • .

row.cell: Factus eſt alter ejus ſiſtendi vas, ut ſi ille non revertiſſet, moriendum eſſet ipſi [for ſibi, i. e. vadi] Cic. Off. 3 Daneſ. Paralip. li. 3. cap. 7. Hawkins Syntax. 37. Not. Scal. de Ling. Lat. li. 6. cap. 130. Farnab. Syſtem. Gram. pag. 53. Aug. Saturn. Mercur. Major. li. 5. cap. 11. & 12.

div.p: ¶ Quintil. Non ſic nuper repugnâſſet, ſi illum [pro ſe] Tribunus voluiſſet occidere, Cic. Offi. 3. Perfuga Fabricco pollicitus eſt, ſi praemium ci [pro ſibi] propoſuiſſet, ſe Pyrrhum veneno necaturum, Cic. Quâ ſocietas hominum inter ipſos [pro ſe] & vitae quaſi communitas continetur.

Fit autem hoc vitandae plerumque ambiguitatis gratiâ: concurrentibus enim pluribus perſonis tertiis, niſi Relativo nonnunquam pro Reciproco licere • uti, obſcura admodum noſtra per ambiguitatem oratio redderetur, ut videre eſt in illo vulgatiſſimo omnium exemplo— R • gavit Nero Epaphroditum, ut ſe occideret—ubi ignoratur uter duorum oocidendus intelligitur; Nerone? an Epaphróditus?

Note 3. Theſe Reciproques Sui Sui enim perinde ac Suus Relativè nonnunquam apud Claſſicos etiam Authores ſumitur. & Suus, are not uſed after a Verb of the firſt, or ſecond Perſon, (unleſs it be when they are put for Relatives) as

cell.hi: I was with him.

row.cell: Cum ego fui [not ſecum.]

cell.hi: Knoweſt thou his brother?

row.cell: Ejus nôſtin' fratrem? [not ſuum.]

div.p: Farn. Syſt. Gram. pag. 53. Daneſ. Paralip. li. 3. cap. 7. Supplem. ad Gram. Ordin.

Mart. li. 6. Ep. 52. Sis licet indè ſibi [pro ipſi] tellus placata leviſque. Senec. ad Albin. Puer ad tuum formetur arbitrium, multum ſibi [pro illi] dabis, etiamſi nihil praeter exemplum dederis. Cic. 1. Philip. Si quid mihi humanitus accidiſſet, hujus dici vocem teſtem reipublicae relinqueremancae
perpetuae erga ſe [pro ipſam] voluntatis. Cic. ad Quir. poſt Red. Qui ſtatuerat Quirites; ſi vos me ſibi [pro illi] non reddidiſſetis, eandem ſubire fortunam.

p.hi: Hujuſmodi autem exempla notanda ut ſint, haud tamen temerè imitanda ſunt.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of the Particle How.
div.p: 1. HOw) before an Adjective, or Adverb of Quality, is I. made by quàm: as

cell.hi: How acceptable doſt thou think this preſent is!

row.cell: Quàm hoc munus gratum arbitrare eſſe!

cell.hi: How fain would I that he were bidden!

row.cell: Quàm vellem eum invitatum!

cell.hi: It cannot be expreſſed, how greatly I reioyce.

row.cell: Non dici poteſt, quàm valdè gaudeam, Cic. 7. Fam. 15. Ep.

div.p: ¶ Si privati tam ponderoſa vox, quàm graves faſces Conſulis extitiſſent! Val. Max. 6. 4. Hei mihi! quàm longè ſpem tulit aura meam! Ov. Am. 1. 6. Is eam rem quàm vehementèr vindicandam putârit, ex decretis ejus poteritis cognoſcere, Cic. pro Quint. Quàm gaudeo! Ter. Ad. 3. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ! [eheu quàm doleo!] Soph. in A • ace. Ah neſcis, quàm doleam, Ter. He. Act. 5. Sc. 1.
2. (How) before words of time or number, is made by quot, II. quotus, or quandiu: as

cell.hi: How old is he?

row.cell: Quot annos natus eſt? [or Quotum annum agit?]

cell.hi: How long is it ſince it was done.

row.cell: Quandiu id factum eſt?

div.p: ¶ Nunc quot modis mutentur dicendum eſt, Cic. Or. Perf. Vidcndum eſt, quandiu retinendum ſit, Cic. Or. Perf.
3. (How) In Interrogation, is made by quid, quomodo, or III. ut: as

cell.hi: How think you?

row.cell: Quid tibi videtur? Ter.

cell.hi: How ſtands the caſe with you?

row.cell: Quomodo tibi res ſe habet?

cell.hi: How fare you?

row.cell: Ut vales?

div.p: ¶ Ut illi efferentur laetitiâ, cùm vicerint? Cic.
4. (How) Vulgarly uſed for that, is expreſſed by quot, ut, IV. or an Infinitive Mood: as

cell.hi: He told his father how [or that] Anthony did beat him.

row.cell: Narravit patri, quòd Antonius eum verberavit.

cell.hi: You know how [i. e. that] I truſt you with all my counſels.

row.cell: Scis, mea confilia ut tibi credam omnia, Ter.

div.p: ¶ Videſne, ut navigia, quae modum excedunt, regi nequeant, Quint. Curt. lib. 4.
5. (How) referring to the meanes, or manner of doing, may V. be expreſſed by quî, quomodo, quemadmodum, ut, uti, unde, quo pacto, quâ ratione, &c. as

cell.hi: How comes it to paſſe, that all men know what I am ignorant of?

row.cell: Quî ſit, ut ego quod neſciam ſciant omnes?

cell.hi: There is no rule given, how the truth may be found out, but onely how it may be iudged of.

row.cell: Nullum eſt praeceptum, quomodo verum inveniatur, ſed tantum quomodo judicetur, Cic.

cell.hi: I would have you ſtudy, how to make me a Library.

row.cell: Velim cogites quemadmodum Bibliothecam nobis conſicere poſſis, Cic.

cell.hi: I think you have heard how they ſtood about me.

row.cell: Credo te audîſſe, ut me circumſteterint, Cic.

cell.hi: And I cannot tell how to avoid it.

row.cell: Neque uti devi • em ſcio, Ter. Phorm.

cell.hi: How knoweſt thou that?

row.cell: Unde id ſcis? Ter.

cell.hi: He cannot tell how to give up his account.

row.cell: Non invenit quo pacto rationem redderet, Val. Max. 3. 1

div.p: ¶ At hoc demiror, quî tam facilè potueris perſuadere illi, Ter Heaut. A. 2. S. 3. Somnum hercle ego hâc nocte oculis non vidi meis, Dum id quaero, tibi quî filium reſtituerem, Ter. He. Act. 3. Sc. 1. Haec negotia quo modo ſe habeant—Cic. 2. Fam. 5. Ep. Quomodo hoc etgo lues? Uno ſcilicet ſi mihi librum miſeris, Cic. ad Att. li. 12. Ep. 6. A principio videndum eſt, quemadmodum velis venire ad extremum, Cic. Or. Quaere potius quemadmodum rationem non reddas, Val. Max. li. 3. cap. 1. Memorat legiones hoſtium ut fugaverit, Plaut. Amph. Prol. Non tu ci dixiſtiut eſſem? Ter. Heaut. 3. 1. Namque videbat uti bellantes Pergama circum hâc fugorent Graii, Virg. Aen. 1. Sed neſcio quo pacto oratio mea defluxit—Cic. Quo autem pacto deceat dici—Cic.

cell.hi: I asked how your ſon did.

row.cell: Quaeſivi de filii tui valetudine

cell.hi: How long, I pray thee, wilt thou abuſe our patience?

row.cell: Quouſque tandem abutêre patientiâ noſtrâ, Cic.

cell.hi: How long is it ere you look for your old man?

row.cell: Quid? Senem quoad expectatis veſtrum? Ter.

cell.hi: They cannot tell how to be angry.

row.cell: Omnino iraſci neſciunt, Cic.

cell.hi: You ſee how all is with us.

row.cell: Vides quo in ſtatu res noſtrae ſint.

div.p: ¶ Cum attendo quâ prudentiâ ſit Hortenſius, Cic. pro Quint.

cell.hi: How great calamities hath he ſuffered?

row.cell: Quantas hauſit calamitates? Cic.

div.p: ¶ Heu! quanto melior ſors tua ſorte meâ eſt! Ovid. Am. 1. 6.

cell.hi: It is not to be ſaid how greatly they reioyce.

row.cell: Dici non poteſt quantopere gaudeant, Cic.

cell.hi: We muſt conſider how far—

row.cell: Videndum eſt quatenus—Cic.

cell.hi: How haſt thou done this long time?

row.cell: Valuiſtin' uſque? Plaut. Stich.

div.p: ¶ 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; Ariſtoph.

cell.hi: How often [or how many times?]

row.cell: Quoties?

div.p: ¶ Ah! quoties per ſaxa canum latratibus acta eſt! Ovid.

cell.hi: It ſhall not repent you how
much you profit.

row.cell: Quantùm proficias non poenitebit, Cic. 1. Off. 1.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of the Particle If.
div.p: 1. IF) in the former clauſe of a conditional ſpeech, is made I. by ſi; in the latter either by ſi, or ſin: as

cell.hi: If Anthony ſhall come hither alone, I think I ſhall eaſily be able of my ſelf to hold him up: but if he ſhall bring any forces with him, I ſhall do my beſt to prevent his doing of harm.

row.cell: Si nudus huc ſe Antonius conferet, facilè mihi videor per me ſuſtinere poſſe: ſi verò copiarum aliquid ſecum adducet, ne quid detrimenti fiat, dabitur opera à me, Cic. Fam. 10. 11.

div.p: ¶ Si • e dolor aliquis tenuit quò minùs ad ludos venires, fortunae magis tribuo, quàm ſapientiae tuae: ſin haec quae caeteri mirantur, contemnenda duxiſti, laetor—Cic. Fam. 7. Ep. 1. Si qua laborioſa eſt, ad me curritur: Sin levis eſt, ad alium mox defertur gregem, Ter. Heaut. Prol. Si quid praeter ſpem erit, facies ut ſciam, ſin eſt (ut arbitror) nego • ium perditum, ſcribes tamen, Cic. Att. 15. 13.
2. (How) ſignifying whether, is made by num, or an, ſeldome II. * by ſi: as

cell.hi: Ask him if [i. e. whether] it be ſo.

row.cell: Ex illo quaeras, num [an] ita ſiet.

cell.hi: I will go ſee if [i. e. whether] he 〈◊〉 at home.

row.cell: Viſam, ſi domi eſt, Ter.

cell.hi: I tried if the winde blew.

row.cell: Tentabam ſpirarent annon aurae, Plaut.

div.p: ¶ Vide—ſi potes eſſe poſſeſſor, Cic. 2. de Orat. Dicito ſi paſcuntur aves, Cic. 2. de Div. Illa ſi jam laverit, mihi nuntia, Ter. Heaut. A. 4. S. 1. Radiorum viribus artus, ſi queat, in vivum tentat revocare calorem, Ovid. 4. Met. v. 248.

* Si pro an rarum eſt, Turſel. cap. 186. Obſer. 3. Nota (inquit Paraeus) ſi, verbis Quaero, ſcire velim, & id genus aliis non adjungi, niſi Praecedente Negatione: ſed pro ſi, an, ne, utrum, nunquid: Inepte igitur dixeris quaero, ſi tibi placeal; pro, quaero an placeat, Paraeus Com. de Partic. p. 542.
3. (If) Immediately before not, is uſually made by ſin, with aliter, III. ſecùs, or minùs; and ſometimes by ſi non, or ſi minùs: as

cell.hi: If that be ſo, all will be the eaſier: but if not, it will be a hard task.

row.cell: Id ſi ita eſt, omnia faciliora: ſin aliter, magnum negotium, Cic. Fam. 11. 14.

cell.hi: If that fall out, that we deſire, we ſhall be glad: if not, we ſhall be content.

row.cell: Si ilud quod volumus eveniet, gaudebimus: ſin ſecùs patiemur animis aequis, Plaut. Caſin.

cell.hi: If I can finiſh it, according to my minde, my labour will be wel beſtowed, but if not, I will throw it into the ſea.

row.cell: Si ex ſententiâ ſucceſſerit, benè erit opera poſita: ſin minus, in ipſum mare dejicimus, Cic. ad Qu. Fr.

cell.hi: He is a great Orator, if not the greateſt.

row.cell: Is magnus eſt Orator, ſi non maximus, Cic. in Orat.

cell.hi: There will be ſomewhat here in ſome time; or if not.

row.cell: Erit hîc aliquid aliquando: aut ſi minùs, Cic. Fam. 7. 11.

div.p:
¶ Si bonus es, obnoxius ſum: ſin ſecùs—Plaut. Trinum. Si uxorem velit, lege id licere facere: ſin aliter negat, Ter. Phorm. Act. 1. Sc. 2. Igitur S. C. ſi erit factum ſcribes ad me: ſin minùs, rem tamen conficies, Cic. Att. 5. 4. Si perficiunt, optimè: ſin minùs—Cic. ad Qu. Fr. 2. 8. Si non perfectio at conatus tamen, Cic. in Oratore. Si me putas te iſtîc viſurum, expectes: ſi minùs, inviſas, Cic.
Att. 3. 19. Quae ut omnia concurrant optabile eſt: ſin minùs, plures cauſae majoreſque ponderis plus habebant, Cic. 1. Off. 16. Huic tu libro maximè velim ex aaimo, ſi minùs, gratiae cauſa ſuffragere, Cic. Fam. 12. 17. Velim antè poſſis ſi minùs, utique ſimul ſimus cùm Brutus veniet, Cic. Att. 13. 4.

4. (If) Parted from not, by other words, is made by ni, niſi, IV. ſin; and ſometimes by
Si non, pro ſi minùs barbarum non eſt, ſi recté adhibeatur, Turſel. cap. 186. obſ. 9. Operae hîc pretium erit • , Parae • Commentar. de Partic. L. L. [p. 543. 545, 546] conſulere. ſi non, and ſi minùs: as

cell.hi: If there were not that cauſe, that

row.cell: Ni eſſet ea cauſa, quam—Cic. Att. 12. 10.

cell.hi: If he had not dem • nded a nights time to conſider on it.

row.cell: Niſi is noctem ſibi ad deliberandnm poſtulâſſet, Cic. ad Quir.

cell.hi: But if you will not have me do it—

row.cell: Sin me id facere noles—Cic. Fam. 2. 1.

cell.hi: If thr great names of my Anceſtors do not ſet me out.

row.cell: Si me non veterum commendant magna parentum Nomina—Ovid. Am. 1. 3.

cell.hi: I reſolved to give you ſome ſmall comfort, that might eaſe your grief, if not cure it.

row.cell: Statui adhibere aliquam modicam conſolationem, quae levare dolorem tuum poſſet, ſi minùs ſanare potuiſſet, Cic. Fam. 5. 16.

div.p: ¶ Nae ego eſſem hîc libentèr, ni eſſet ea cauſa, quàm tibi ſuperioribus literis ſcripſi, Cic. ad Art. 12. Ep. 10. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , [Et niſi Deorum aliquis hunc conatum reſtinxiſſet] Soph. Ajax. Niſi nota eſſe arbitrarer, Cic. Niſi moderationem animi tui notam haberem, Quint. Curt. l. 4. Domitius (niſi me omnia fallunt) de ſe incredibiliter timuit, Cic. Att. l. 1. Turſel. cap. 125. Obſ. 1. Si mihi tecum non & multae & juſtae cauſae amicitiae privatim eſſent, Cic. Fam. 6. 17.
5. (If) before any is made by ſi, either joyned to quis, &c. V. or pa • ted from it by other words: as

cell.hi: If you can by any means—

row.cell: Siquo pacto pores, Cic.

cell.hi: If there be any faith in me.

row.cell: Siqua fides, Mart. li. 1. Ep. 14.

cell.hi: If any man man bring yo • into queſtion.

row.cell: Si re in judicium quis adducat, Cic.

div.p: ¶ Siqua pios reſpectant numina: ſiquid uſquam juſtitiae eſt, Virg. Aen. 1. Malè cum credo intollexiſſe, ſi quiſquam malè intelligit, Cic. Att. 16. 14. Si forte armenta requiret Haec aliquis, vidiſſe nega, Ovid. Met. 2. 699.

cell.hi: As if [Vide As]

row.cell: Ac ſi, utſi, quaſi, perinde qaaſi, tanquam.

div.p: ¶ Ejus negotium ſic velim ſuſcipi •• , ut ſi 〈◊〉 res mea, Cic. Fam. 2. 14. Similiter fa • iunt, ut ſi—Cic. Offic. 1.

cell.hi: I do not ſpeak it, as if I made any doubt of your honeſty.

row.cell: Non eò dico, quò mihi veniat in dubium fides tua, Cic. pro Quint.

div.head: CHAP. XX. Of the Particle In.
div.p: 1. IN) before the name, or Author of a Book, is made by I. apud: as

row.cell: I had heard it, as it is in Brutus [i. e. the book ſo called.]
Sic acceperam, ut apud Brutum eſt, Cic. Att. 12. 5.

div.p: ¶ Tranſlatio eſt apud cum multa, Cic. Eſt apud cundem, Cic. Or. Veteres id dicere ſolitos apparet apud Plautum, Va ro de Ling. Lat. lib. 4. De quâ praeclarè apud cundem eſt Platonem, Cic. Off. 1. Quod apud Platonem eſt in Philoſophos dictum, Cic. 1. Offic. 12. Quod enim eſt apud Ennium—id latiùs patet, Cic. 1. Off. 10.
2. (In) before the names of Languages [as in Engliſh, in Latine, II. &c.] is made by an Adverb: as

cell.hi: To ſpeak in Greek.

row.cell: Graecè loqui, Cic. Or.

div.p: ¶ Hoc loco continetur id quod dici Latinè decorum poteſt: Graecè enim 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dicitur, Cic. Offic. 1. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; Acts 21. 37.
3. (In) before the Engliſh of the Participle of the III. preſent See the marginal notes to the fift Rule. Tenſe is made by in, or inter, with a Gerund or Gerundive Adjective: as

cell.hi: They ſpend the day in making ready.

row.cell: In apparando conſumunt diem—

cell.hi: It freezeth in the falling.

row.cell: Inter decidendum gelaſcit.

cell.hi: In the amplifying of a thing.

row.cell: In amplificandâ re, Cic. Or.

div.p: ¶ Qui in ulciſcendo remiſſior fuerit mox apertè laudatur: at qui in beneficiis romunerandis eſt tardior ingratus appelletur neceſſe eſt, Cic. ad Quir.
4. (In) before words of price, is ſigne of an Ablative caſe: IV. as

cell.hi: It ſtood me in three 〈◊〉 .

row.cell: Tribus mihi denariis ſtetit.

div.p: 5. (In) Without to, is generally a ſigne of the V. Ablative After Adjectives importing skill or unskilfulneſs, the word following in, is ſometimes made by the Genitive caſe: ſometimes by a Gerund in di: as, Skilful in the Lawes. Legum peritus, Hor. Skilfull in ſhooting. Peritus jaculandi. Ʋnskilful in Greek letters. Graeoarum literarum rudis, Cic. Off. 1. caſe: as

cell.hi: I came in time.

row.cell: In tempore veni.

cell.hi: Ignorant in the civil law.

row.cell: Rudis in jure civili, Cic. lib. 1. de Orat.

div.p: 6. (In) with to, requireth an Accuſative * caſe: as VI.

cell.hi: He came into the Senate.

row.cell: In Senatum venit, Cic.

cell.hi: She 〈◊〉 into a cave.

row.cell: Fugit in antrum, Ovid.

div.p:
* Eſt tamen ubi Authores, imitati Graecos 〈◊〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,
& contrá, ut
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Hom.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , promiſcuè vel Accuſat. vel Ablativum huic Praepoſitioni ſubjiciunt. Sic Ovid. 2 Met. Utinamque oculos in pectore poſſes inſerere. Cic. pro Quint. Veni in Senatu. Sen. 3. de Ben. 6. 37. In ordine redigere. Vide Durrer. Daneſ. Farnab.

Note 1. There be many Latine phraſes, in whoſe Engliſh in muſt be rendered without to, Sic, ad ſummum, [in brief] Cic. In medium, [in common] Virg. In orbem [In a ring] Ovid. In gyrum, Ovid. Animi pendeo, Cael. Ciceroni. Deſipiebam mentis, Plaut. In rem tuam erit. [It will ſtand you in ſtead.] Quid? quod apud Terentium legimus. Eſſe in magnum honorem, Eun. Act. 2. Sc. 2. Et apud Ciceronem—Eſſe in amicitiam populi Romani, CIc. 1. Verr. Voſſ. Gram. p. 84. Durrer. de Parti • . p. 202. though the following Subſtantive be not of the Ablative caſe: as

cell.hi: I am troubled in minde.

row.cell: Diſcrucior animl, Plaut.

cell.hi: A gallant •• vie in ſhew, but poor and weak.

row.cell: Praeclara claſſis in ſpeciem, ſed inops & infirma, Cic. 7. Verr.

div.p: Note 2. Into after a Latine Verb compounded with in, is oftentimen part of the ſignification (and included in the Latine) of that verb: as

cell.hi: To enter into an houſe.

row.cell: Domum ingredi.

div.p: ¶ Inſilui campo, Claud. Inſiluere vadis, Stat. Modo ſeriùs incidis undis, Ovid. Met. 4. v. 198.

cell.hi: He came in the night.

row.cell: De nocte venit, Cic.

cell.hi: In the dark.

row.cell: Per tenebras, Ovid.

div.p: ¶ At priùs Aeneas per noctem plurima volvens, Virg. Aen. 1. Callida per tenebras verſato cardine Thisbe egreditur, Ovid. Met. 4. Nec dubitavi quin per eos dies matutina tempora lectinnculis conſumpſeris, Cic. Fam. 7. 1. Quod ſi tu per eos dies operam dediſti Protogeni tuo—Id. ib.

row.cell: In his ſleep.
Secundùm quie • em, Sen.
In the mean while.
Interim
Inter haec
Interea loci, Ter. Eun. 1. 2.
In faith [troth.]
Hercle. Mehercle.
You come in good time.
Per tempus advenis, Ter.
In that place.
Eò loci, Val. Max.
In word onely.
Verbo tenus, Cic.
In compariſon of whom—
Prae quo—
In the Pulpit.
Pro ſuggeſtu.
Pro roſtris.
¶ Pro concione, Liv. 38.

cell.hi: Not well in his wits.

row.cell: Non eſt compos mentis.
Sui eſt inops animi
Get you in.
Abi intrò. Ter. Heaut.

In time
paſt. Alium eſſe cenſes nunc me, atque olim quum dabam, Ter.
to come. Forſon, & haec olim meminiſſe juvabit, Virg.
Olim.

cell.hi: It will ſtand you in ſome ſtead.

row.cell: In rem tuam
erit.
E re tua

div.p: ¶ Id fac, quod in rem ſit tuam, Ter. Hec.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of the Particle Long.
div.p: 1. LOng) Joyned with all, is made by omnis, or totus: as I.

cell.hi: I have not ſeen him all this day long.

row.cell: Hodie toto non vidi die, Ter.

cell.hi: All my life long.

row.cell: In omni vitâ, Cic.

div.p: ¶ Nihi totâ viâ, quàm eſſetne ſibi ſalvum imperium requirens, Suet. apud Steu • ch.
2. (Long of) denoting one to be the cauſe of, occaſional to, II. or in fault for a thing, is made by in cauſa, in culpa, or elſe by ſome third perſon of ſto or ſio; thus,

cell.hi: It ſhall not be long of me—

row.cell: Ipſe in culpâ non ero—
Per me non ſtabit, quo minus—

cell.hi: It was long of you that he was condemned.

row.cell: Tu in cauſa damnationis fuiſti, Quint.
Per te factum eſt, ut condemnatur.

div.p: ¶ Per eos factum eſt, quo minus, Cic. 1. Ep. 4.
3. (Long) ſignifying greatly to deſire, is to be tranſlated by III. a verb ſignifying ſo: viz. cupio, ſuſpiro, gliſco, ardeo, &c. as

cell.hi: He longs to ſee you.

row.cell: Cupit te videre.

div.p: ¶ Aliquid immenſum deſiderant, Cic. Quae plerique vehementer expetunt, pro nihilo ducunt, Cic. 1. Off.
4. (Long) in other ſignifications, is an Adverb, or an Adjective IV. either of Time or Meaſure: as

cell.hi: I am ſorry you were ſo long away from us.

row.cell: Ego te abfuiſſe tamdiu à nobis doleo, Cic.

cell.hi: You have ſtaid me long.

row.cell: Diu me eſtis demorati, Plaut.

cell.hi: So long as I ſhall live.

row.cell: Dum animâ ſpirabo meâ, Cic.

cell.hi: So long as you ſhall be in proſperity.

row.cell: Donec eris foelix.

cell.hi: I think good that you hide your ſelf ſo long there, till

row.cell: Cenſeo tibi latendum tantiſper ibidem, dum—

cell.hi: A long war.

row.cell: Bellum longum [diutinum, diuturnum.]

cell.hi: Seven foot long.

row.cell: Septem pedes longus.

div.p:
¶ Haec autem forma retinenda non diu eſt, Cic. Or. Perf. Quam 〈◊〉
quiſquam erit, qui te defendere audeat, Cic. Quouſque poſcimus aliquid Deos? Sen. Ep. 60. Tamdiu requieſco, quamdiu ad te ſcribo, Cic. Att. l. 9. Ep. 3.—quoad [ſo long as] te quantum proficias non poenitebit, Cic. 1. Off. 1. Herilli jam pridem [long ago] exploſa ſententia eſt, Cic. 1. Off. 1. Quoad quiſ
que eorum vixerit [ſo long as] Cic. 1. Off. 15. Uſque dum vivunt, Plaut. Trucul. A. 2. Sc. 3.

cell.hi: It will come, ere it be long

row.cell: Jam hîc
ader • t.
Brevi

cell.hi: It is not loug ſince.

row.cell: Haud diu eſt quum.

cell.hi: Not very long after.

row.cell: Haud
ità multò poſt.
Non

cell.hi: He ſtaid longer then was expected.

row.cell: Ampliùs opinione morabatur Sal.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Of the Particle Man.
div.p: MAn) If ſpoken by way of oppoſition, either to childe, or I. woman, is made by vir: as

cell.hi: When I was a child I ſpake as a childe: but when I became a man, I put away childiſh things.

row.cell: Quum eſſem infans, ut infans loquebar: poſtquam autem factus ſum vir, abolevi quae inſantis erant.

cell.hi: Neither do the Roman women ſwear by Hercules, nor the men by Caſtor.

row.cell: Neque mulieres Romanae per Herculem dejurant, neque viri per Caſtorem.

div.p:
¶ Togatus à praetextato differt, ut privatus à magiſtratu, & vir à
puero. Pellit. in Or. pro A. Caecin. Hinc ubi jam firmata virum tc fecerit aetas, Virg. Ecl. 4. Qui conjectare quâ mares, quâ foeminas. Plaut. Mil. apud Paraeum de Partic. pag. 360. Eum oderunt quâ viri, quâ mulieres, Liv. apud eundem, ib. Sic quidem viri, ſed ne qui ſexus à laude ceſſaret, Ecce & virginum virtus, Flor. 1. 10. Jusjurandum autem per Pollucem & viro & foeminae commune eſt, A. Gel. 4. 1.
2. (Man) Relating to the nature of man, without reſpect II. either to ſex or age, is made by homo: as

cell.hi: Man is a mortall living creature, capable of reaſon and of knowledge.

row.cell: Homo eſt mortale animal rationis & ſcientiae capiens, A. Gell.

div.p: ¶ Eſt natura hominum novitatis avida, Plin. Ità eſt vita hominum quaſi cùm ludas teſſeris, Ter. Ad. Homo ſum; humani nihil à me alienum puto, Ter.
3. (Man) If it be referred to the quality of any determinate III. Perſon, it is made by either vir, or homo: as

cell.hi: If we will ſhew our ſelves to be men, [i. e. ſtout men.]

row.cell: Si viri eſſe volumus, Cic.

cell.hi: Thou art a man [i. e. a ſtout man.]

row.cell:
Homo
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
es, Plaut.

cell.hi: Good men do theſe things to the moſt eſtranged men.

row.cell: Haec in homines alieniſſimos viri boni faciunt, Cic.

div.p: ¶ Virum res illa quaerebat, Cic. Ità eſt homo, Ter. Tulit dolorem ut vir; & ut homo majorem ferre ſine cauſâ neceſſariâ noluit, Cic. Patre ejus claro homine, & forti viro plurimùm uſi ſumus, Cic. 6. F. 11. Ep.
4. (Man) ſpoken indefinitely, without respect to any determinate IV. perſon, is made by ullus, nullus, nemo, quis, or ſome compound thereof with homo [either expreſſed * or] underſtood: as

cell.hi: If any man call, I will come inſtantly.

row.cell: Si ullus vocabit, ſtatim veniam.

cell.hi: No man can do it better then you.

row.cell: Hoc melius, quam tu, facere nemo poteſt, Cic.

cell.hi: A man may ask, what had you to do with her?

row.cell: Roget quis, quid tibi cum illâ? Ter.

cell.hi: If any man bring you into queſtion.

row.cell: Si te in judicium quis adducat, Cic.

cell.hi: And is there any man that knowing this, can ſuſpect?

row.cell: Et eſt quiſquam, qui cùm hoc cognôrit ſuſpîcari poſſit?

cell.hi: Every man loves himſelf.

row.cell: Se quiſque diligit.

cell.hi: Is any man alive more fortunate then I am?

row.cell: Ecquis me vivit hodie fortunatior? Ter.

cell.hi: If any man chance to ask for theſe cattel, ſay you ſaw them not.

row.cell: Si fortè armenta requiret haec aliquis, vidiſſe nega, Ov.

div.p: ¶ * Sic ſemper dilexi, ut non ullo cum homine conjunctiùs viverem, Cic. 6. Fam. 11. Ep. Nullus frugi eſſe poteſt homo, niſi qui benè & malè facere tenet, Plaut. Neminem hominem pluris facio, Cic. Eſt enim vis tanta naturae, ut homo nemo velit, niſi hominis ſimilis eſſe, Cic. Nunquis hinc me ſequitur? Nemo homo eſt, Ter. Ego formidoloſus? Nemo eſt hominum, qui vivat minus, Ter. De quo homine praeconis vox praedicat, & pretium conficit, huic acerbiſſimum vivo videntique fumus ducitur, Cic. pro Quint. An quiſquam hominum eſt aequè miſer ut ego? An hoc dubitavit quiſquam omnium? Cic. Jugulari civem nè jure quidem quiſquam bonus vult, Cic. Suam quiſque homo rem meminit, Plaut. Quiſnam homo eſt, Ter. Cicero ſeems to uſe homo alone in this indefinite ſenſe, Orat. pro Quint. Etſi homini nihil magìs eſt optandum quàm proſpera fortuna, ib. Quid homini poteſt turpius uſu venire?
5. (Man) Put for man-ſervant, in ſuch like expreſſions as V. theſe [My man, yours, or his man] is made by ſervus or famulùs: as

cell.hi: I received your letters of your man.

row.cell: Redditae mihi ſunt literae tuae famulo tuo.

cell.hi: He ſent his footman to Rome.

row.cell: Servum à pedibus Romam miſit, apud Durrer.

div.p:
¶ Cúm ex eo curioſe quaeſiſſet ſervus noſter, Cic. ad Att. 9. 3. Cicero uſes homo in this ſenſe too, Orat. pro Quint. Hominem
P. Quintii deprehendis in publico [i. e. P. Quintius his man.]

cell.hi: He plaid the man.

row.cell: Virum egit.
Se virum praeſtitit.

cell.hi: He is grown a man.

row.cell: Togam virilem ſumpſit.
Ex ephebis exceſſit.

div.p: ¶ Cùm ſapimus patruos, Perſ.

cell.hi: A manor a mouſe.

row.cell: Aut Caeſar aut nullus.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. Of the Particle More.
div.p: 1. MOre) before an Adverb or Adjective of quality, is I. made by their comparative degree; or by magìs, with their poſitive, especially if they form no regular comparative: as

cell.hi: He is more greedy of pleaſure then of money.

row.cell: Cupidior eſt voluptatis, quàm pecuniae.

cell.hi: If I muſt ſpeak more plainly.

row.cell: Si dicendum eſt apertiús.

cell.hi: More fit.

row.cell: Magis idoneus,

cell.hi: More fitly.

row.cell: Magis idoneé.

div.p: ¶ Renovata illuſtriora videntur, quam ſi obſcurata non eſſent, Cic. ad Quir. De quo eſt accuratius diſputandum, Cic. Orat.
2. (More) When it referres to quantity, and when it may be varied by above, greater, or more greatly, is made by plus: as II.

cell.hi: There were more then [or above] fifty men ſlain.

row.cell: Plus quinquaginta hominum ceciderunt, Liv.

cell.hi: One hath more [or greater] ſtrength then another.

row.cell: Plus habet virium alius alio.

cell.hi: I have no man, to whom I am more [or more greatly] indebted, than to you.

row.cell: Ego habeo cui plus, quàm tibi debeam neminem, Cic.

cell.hi: I do not give you way to love him more [or greatlier] than I love him my ſelf.

row.cell: Non concedo tibi, plus ut illum ames, quàm ipſe amo, Cic. ad Qu. Fr.

div.p: ¶ Fortunae meae recuperatae plus mihi nunc voluptatis afferunt, Cic. ad Quir. Plus trecenta vehicula amiſſa, Liv. Non habet plus ſapientiae quàm lapis, Plaut. Re plus quam opinione differens, Cic. Ex eâ re plus mali eſt, quam commodi utrique, Ter. And. Quae exiſtimas plus quam artem ipſam prodeſſe, Cic. de Orat. More greatly is ſometimes the Engliſh of magis: as Deſiderata magis, quam percepta delectant, Cic. Sic fruebar, ut nemo magis, Cic. Me non magis liber ipſe delectabit, quam tua admiratio delectavit, Cic. ad Att. 12. 6. Magis offendit nimium, quam parùm, Cic.
3. (More) When it is put for rather, is moſt uſually made by III. magis: as

cell.hi: I knew it more [or rather] by what I tried, then by what I had learned.

row.cell: Experiendo magis, quam diſcendo cognovi, Cic.

cell.hi: I attribute it more to fortune, then to any wiſdom of yours.

row.cell: Fortunae magis tribuo, quam ſapientiae tuae, Cic. Fam. 7. Ep. 1.

div.p: ¶ Carendo magis intellexi, quàm fruendo. Cic. Ut magìs virtute, quam dolo contenderent. Ceſ. Turſell. de Part. cap. 106. Non temere Magis pro Plus uſurpandum eſt. Magis enim plerunque ad comparationem pertinet, & Potius ſignificat. Plus autem ſaepe refertur ad magnitudinem, & contrarium habet Minus, &c.

4. (More) In speeches of this kinde, [The more learned IV. thou art, the more humble be thou] in the firſt place is to be made by quo or quanto, in the ſecond by eo or tanto, and in both is to have a Comparative degree after it: as Quanto doctior es, tanto ſubmiſſior fueris.

¶ Quanto diutius abeſt, magis cupio tanto, & magis deſidero, Ter. Heaut. Quanto ſpei eſt minus, tanto magis amo, Ter. Eun. Quanto plura parâſti, tanto plura cupis, Hor. Quanto ſplendidior—Tanto praeſtantior, Ovid. 2. 724. Quo difficilius hoc praeclarius, Cic. Quoque magis tegitur, tanto magis aeſtuat ignis, Ovid. Met. 2. Quae quo plura ſunt, eo te meliori mente noſtra verba audire oportebit, Cic. pro Quint. Quo plus propter virtutem poſſunt, eo minus quid poſſint debent oſtendere, Cic. Etſi eſt eo laudabilior, Cic. Quo etiam ſatietas formidanda eſt magis, Cic. Quo gratior tua liberalitas nobis debet eſſe, Cic.
Note 1. In ſuch like expreſſions as theſe [in Rule 4.] there is a defect of theſe words [by how much, or by ſo much] which are many times expreſſed.
Note 2. Magis * hath both the nature, and the regiment of a Comparative.

¶ * Saturnius diſtinguens inter elementum comparandi, & comparativum, negat magis eſſe per ſe comparativum [l. 9. c. 6.] At non prudenter inquit Scaliger, [de cauſ. L. Lat. l. 4. c. 101.] qui a Poſitivo magnum, format comparativum magis. Cui aſſentitur Laur. Valla. [l. 1. c. 12.] Nec diverſum ab his ſentire videtur, Farnab. qui [Syntax. Regim. Reg. 52.] comparativi regimen huic Adverbio tribuit, authoritate nixus Virgilii Aen. 1. Quam Juno fertur terris magis omnibus unam coluiſſe.

row.cell: So as nothing can be more.
Ut nihil
ultra
poſſit.
ſupra
More than once, or twice.
Iterum, & ſaepius, Cic.
I deſired nothing more.
Nihil mihi potius fuit.
Nihil eſt quod malim quam—
We deſire no more.
Nihil [non] deſideramus amplius, Cic.
He did no more.
Non ultra quam—

div.p: ¶ Non ultra, quam compedibus coercuit, Sueton.

row.cell: Nothing troubled me more.
Nihil me magis ſollicitabat, quam—Cic.

div.p: ¶ Quo magis cavendum eſt ne-Cic. 1. Offic. 10.

row.cell: He ſaid there was one and no more.
Unum aiebat, praeterea neminem, Cic.
I take more care how to—than—
Mihi majori curae eſt quemadmodum—quam—Cic.
I love him every day more and more.

Quem me hercule plus pluſ
que in dies diligo, Cic.

div.p: ¶ Amor mihi creſcit in horas, Virg.

row.cell: I think every day more and more of—
Quotidie magis, ac magis cogito de—Cic.

div.p: ¶ Quotidie augeſcit magis aegritudo, Ter. He. 3. 1.

row.cell: I ſell for no more then others do.
Non vendo pluris quam alii.

cell.hi: Moreover.

row.cell: Quin etiam. Atque etiam.
So as they may moſt fitly hang together.
Ita ut quam aptiſſimè cohaereant, Cic.
As every one ſtands moſt in need of help.
Ut quiſque maximè opis indigear, Cic.
For the moſt pare.
Magnam partem.
Magna ex parte.
Maxima parte.

div.p: ¶ Maximam autem partem ad injuriam faciendam aggrediuntur, ut—Cic. 1. Off. 10.

row.cell: As moſt of us ſpeak.
Ut plerique loquimur, Cic.
Moſt of all.
Vel maxime, Cic.

div.p: ¶ Maxime autem adducuntur plerique, ut Cic. 1. Off. 10.

row.cell: At the moſt.
Summum.
Ad ſummum.
Ut maxime.
As moſt an end it comes to paſſe.
Quod plerunque fit.
Ut ferè fit.

div.p: ¶ In ſplendidiſſimis ingeniis plerunque exiſtunt honoris imperii—cupiditates, Cic. 1. Off. 10.

row.cell: All for the moſt part.
Plerique omnes, Ter.

div.p: ¶ Quod plerique omnes faciunt adoleſcentuli—Ter. And. 1. 1.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV. Of the Particle Much.
div.p: 1. MUch) joyned to a Subſtantive expreſſed, is made by I. multus or plurimus: as

cell.hi: That is a matter of much difficulty

row.cell: Sudores multi eſt res illa.

cell.hi: In this kinde there is very little ſtrength, yet much ſweetneſſe.

row.cell: Hoc in genere nervorum eſt vel minimum, ſuavitatis autem vel plurimum, Cic.

div.p: ¶ Multo ſanguine, ac vulneribus ea Poenis victoria ſtetit, Liv. Quantum quiſque ſuâ nummorum ſervat in arcâ, Tantum habet & fidei, Juvenal.

2. (Much) Without a Subſtantive, and relating to price, II. value, or * concernment, is made respectively by ſome of theſe words, (a) quanti, (a) tanti, hujus, (b) magni, [or (b) magno] (b) permagni, maximi, plurimi, [or (c) plurimo:] as

cell.hi: Conſider not how much the man is to be eſteemed.

row.cell: Noli ſpectare quanti homo ſit Cic.

cell.hi: Priamus was hardly worth ſo much.

row.cell: Vix Priamus tanti fuit, Ovid.

cell.hi: I value you not thus much.

row.cell: Non hujus re facio, Val. Max.

cell.hi: How much do you regard his authority in the Senate.

row.cell: Suam in Senatu authoritatem quam magni aeſtimans? Cic.

cell.hi: Vertue is much to be valued in every place.

row.cell: Magno ubique virtus aeſtimanda eſt.

cell.hi: I have deſervedly ever eſteemed you very much.

row.cell: Meritò te ſemper maximi feci, Ter.

cell.hi: Money is every where very much eſteemed.

row.cell: Plurimi paſſim fit pecunia

div.p: ¶ (a) Hoc ſi quanti tu aeſtimes ſciam, tum—Cic. ad Att. 1. 6. Non tanti emo poenitere, A. Gell. (a) Pro Genitivis tanti & quantl junguntur nonnunquam cum verbo intereſt Adverbia, tantum & quantum, Plin. l. 2. c. 16. Tantùm intereſt ſubeant radii, an ſuperveniant, Cic. pro Muraena. Quantùm communis ſalutis interſit, Daneſ. Schol. l. 3. c. 9. (b) Magni intereſt ad decus, & laudem hujus civitatis ita fieri, Cic. Data magno aeſtimans, accepta parvo, Sen. 3. de Ira. Non fames nobis ventris noſtri magno conſtat, ſed ambitio, Sen. 60. Ep. Permagni intereſt, quo tempore haec epiſtola tibi reddita ſit, Cic. Illud permagni referre arbitror, Ter. Heaut. 3. 1. (c) Farnab. ad Regim. Synt. reg. 48.
* Equidem ad noſtram laudem non multùm video intereſſe, Cic. Plurimum refert compoſitionis, quae quibus anteponas, Quintil.
3. (Much) When it is joyned with a Verb, and may be rendered III. by far, or greatly, is made by multùm, quantùm, magnopere, vehementer, longè, valde, &c. as

cell.hi: He is much [or greatly] deceived

row.cell: Multum fallitur.
As much [or as far] as lies in me. *
Quantum in me erit, Cic.

cell.hi: I do not much [or greatly] care.

row.cell: Non magnopere laboro, Cic.

cell.hi: He is much [or greatly] miſtaken.

row.cell: Vehementer errat, Cic.

cell.hi: It much [or far] excells all other Studies and Arts.

row.cell: Longè caeteris & Studiis & Artibus antecedit, Cic.

cell.hi: I am much [or greatly] afraid.

row.cell: Valde timeo, Cic.

div.p: ¶ Multum ille & terris jactatus & alto, Aen. 1.
* Quod potero, Ter. Heaut. 3. 1. Pro viribus. Pro virili meâ parte.
Te iſtam tam tenuem 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tam valde admiratum eſſe gaudeo, Cic. Malè metuo, Plaut. Non mediocriter pertimeſco, Cic.
4. (Much) Sometimes is part of the ſignification of the immediatly IV. foregoing verb: as

cell.hi: You are a fine man, to think much, to ſend me a letter.

row.cell: Jam lautus es, qui gravere ad me literas dare, Cic.

div.p: 5. (Much) before the Comparative and Superlative degree V. is made by tanto, quanto, multo, longe; and before the Comparative alſo by quo, eo, hoc, and haud paulo: as

cell.hi: By how much the leſſe hope there is, by ſo much the more am I in love.

row.cell: Quanto minus ſpei eſt, tanto magìs amo, Ter. Eun. Sc. ult.

cell.hi: You are by ſo much the worſt Poet of sll, by how much you are the beſt Patron of all.

row.cell: Tanto tu peſſimus omnium Poeta, quanto tu optimus omnium Patronus, Catull.

cell.hi: You are much more ſkilful, yet not much better then other men.

row.cell: Longè caeteris peritior es, ſed non multo melior tamen.

cell.hi: I now think my ſelf to be much the happieſt man alive.

row.cell: Multo omninm nunc me fortunatiſſimum puto eſſe, Ter.

cell.hi: He is in ſo much the better ſtate.

row.cell: Eo eſt meliore conditione, &c. *

div.p: ¶ Quanto diutius abeſt, magis cupio tanto, & magìs deſidero, Ter. Heaut. 3. 1. Hic mihi quanto plus ſapit, quàm egomet mihi! Ter. Heaut. 3. 1. Omne animi vitium tanto conſpectius in ſe Crimen habet, quanto major qui peccat habetur, Juvenal. Quanto ſuperiores ſimus, tanto nos ſummiſſiùs geramu • , Cic. Off. 1. Haud ſcio an multo magis etiam deſpicientia adhibenda ſit rerum humanarum, Cic. Off. Id quod multo magìs eſt admirandum, Cic.

* Vir longè poſt homines natos improbiſſimus, Cic. in Brut. Hominem longè audaciſſimum nuper habuimus in civitate Fimbriam, Cic. pro Roſc. Am. Quarum rerum
eo gravior dolor, quo culpa major, Cic. ad Att. 11. 11. Arationes eo fructuoſiores ſiunt, quo calidiore terra aratur, Varro de re ruſtie. l. 1. cap. 32. Quo difficilius, hoc praeclarius, Cic. Off. 1. Quo quiſque ingenio minus valet, hoc ſe magis attollere, & dilatare conatur, Quintil. 2. l. 1.
〈◊〉 . 3. Nae tu haud paulo plus, quàm quiſquam noſtrûm delectationis habuiſti, Cic. 7. lib. Fam. Ep. 1.

row.cell: Much good d'it you.
Sit ſaluti. Proſi • .
Bene ſit tibi cum—
He is much a Scholar.
Vir eſt haud vulgariter doctus.
Eſt homo non contemnendae doctrinae.
I underſtand as much.
Tantundem intelligo, Plaut.

div.p: ¶ Non recuſo, quin, quantum de illo libro, tantundem de mei judicii famâ detrahatur, Cic. 6. Ep. 19.

row.cell: He could not ſo † much as ſay, much * leſs could he ſing.
Ne loqui quidem potuit, nedum cantare.

div.p: ¶ † Ne calamiſtri quidem adhibebuntur, Cic. Or. Ne epiſtola quidem narrare audeo tibi—Cic. l. 2. Fam. Ep. 5.
* Satrapes ſi ſiet amator, nunquam ſnfferre ejus ſumptus queat, nedum tu poſſis, Ter. Heaut. 3. 1.

row.cell: He is much in debt.
Aere alieno obrutus eſt.
Ex aere alieno labora • .
We had much ado to perſwade him.
Difficulter ei perſuaſum eſt.
Not ſo much to perſwade, as to delight.
Non tam perſuadere quàm delectare.

div.p: ¶ Non tam ut te impedirent, quàm ut—Cic. Non tam ſui conſervandi cauſâ, quam, Cic. Cat. 1.

row.cell: They can do much with him.
Plurimum apud eum poſſunt.
Between too much and too little.
Inter nimium & parum—Cic. Off. 1.
So much as—i. e. onely.
Tantum

cell.hi: I am not ſo mu • h a Traveller abroad, as I was wont to be.

row.cell: Non tam ſum peregrinator jam, quam ſolebam, Cic. 6. Ep. 19.

div.head: CHAP. XXV. Of the Particles Muſt or Ought.
div.p: 1. MUſt or Ought) is generally made in Latine by oporter, I. debeo, or a Gerund in dum: as

cell.hi: He muſt [or ought to] have ſome iuice.

row.cell: Habeat ſuccum aliquem oportet, Cic.

cell.hi: He muſt [or ought to] be a man of great skill.

row.cell: Summae vir facultatis eſſe debebit, Cic.

cell.hi: But an Orator muſt [or ought to] conſider.

row.cell: Eſt autem Oratori videndum, Cic.

div.p: ¶ Multa oportet diſcat, atque dediſcat, Cic. pro Quint. Quod jam pridem factum eſſe oportuit, Cic. Cat. 1. Saepius cogitant quid poſſit, quam quid debeat facere, Cic. pro Quint. Si grati eſſe volunt, debebunt Pompeium hortari, ut—Cic. Att. 9. 8. Orandum eſt, ut ſit mens ſana in corpore ſano, Juvenal. Etenim ex rerum cognitione e •• loreſcat, & redundet oportet oratio, Cic. l. 1. de Orat. apud Com. Gall. Lat. Sunt enim per multa quibus erit medendum, Id. ib.
2. (Ought) ſignifying any thing is made by quid, ecquid, ſiquid, II. aliquid, quicquam, or quidpiam: as

cell.hi: If you do ought alone.

row.cell: Si tecum agas quid, Cic. 1. Off.
He asked him if he ſaw ought, Mark 8. 23.
Interrogavit eum ecquid [or ſiquid] videret, Bez. Hieron.
—If thou remembreſt that thy brother hath ought againſt thee— Matth. 5. 23.
Si memineris fratrem tuum habere aliquid contra te, Bez. Hieron.
Neither haſt thou taken ought of any mans hand, 1. Sam. 12. 4.
Neque accepiſti quicquam [quippiam] è manu ullius, Jun. Hieron.

div.p: ¶ Ecquid vides? Ecquid ſentis? Cic. in Piſon. Cave quicquam, niſi quod rogabo te, mihi reſponderis, Plaut. Amphit.
3. (Ought) Joyned with for is many times put for, as far as, III. and then is made by quantum: as

cell.hi: For ought [or as far as] I ſee.

row.cell: Quantum ego perſpicio, Cic.

div.p: ¶ Quantum ego intelligere potueram, Cic. apud Turſel. de Partic. c. 163. Obſ. 1. Vide etiam Paraeum de Partic. p. 372.

Note. When the Gerund neceſſarily governs an Accuſative caſe, it is then more elegant to turn that Accuſative into a Nominative and the Gerund in dum into a Participial in dus, agreeing with that Nominative caſe: as, this Engliſh, I muſt [or ought to] love my father, is not ſo well rendered in Latine by Amandum * eſt mihi patrem, as by Amandus eſt mihi pater.

¶ * Sic tamen locutus eſt, Varr • de R. R. l. 1. cap. 21. Canes potius cum dignitate & acres paucos habendum, quam multos. Sic Livius, l. 37. Conclamatum propè ab univerſo Senatu eſt, perdomandum feroces animos eſſe. Sic Lucretius, l. 1. Aeternas quoniam poenas in morte timendum. Quin & Virgilius ſemel, Aen. 11. Aut pacem Trojano à rege petendum. Diſceſſi ab eo bello, in quo aut in acie cadendum fuit, aut in aliquas inſidias incidendum, aut deveniendum in victoris manus, aut capiendus tanquam exilio locus, aut conſciſcenda mors voluntaria, Cic. l. 7. Fam. Ep. 3. Contemnendus eſt omnis dolor. Id. apud Commiſſur. Gall. Lat. p. 131.

p.hi: Imitati autem ſunt hoc loquendi modo Graecorum conſtructionem.

div.p:
Sic quippe Demoſth.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Latis legibus utendum, novae verò nou temerè ferendae: ad verbum; Novas verò non temerè ferendum. Sic Xenoph.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Vide Daneſii Scholien. li. 3. cap. 15. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Si ab amicis diligi vis, amici beneficiis afficiendi ſunt: ad verbum; amicos beneficiis afficiendum. Plut. in Paedag.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 —

row.cell: It muſt by all means be kept cloſe.
Quoquo pacto tacito eſt opus, Ter.
It muſt needs be ſo.
Fieri a liter non poteſt, Ter.
I muſt take care it be not done.
Id nè fiat mihi cautio eſt.

div.p: ¶ Piſces ex ſententiâ nactus ſum: hi mihi nè corrumpantur, cautio eſt, Ter. Ad. A. 3. Sc. 3.

row.cell: We ſee what ought to be.
Quid doceat videmus, Cic. Or.
As it muſt needs be.
Id quod neceſſe eſt, Cic.

div.p: ¶ Impius appelletur neceſſe eſt, Cic. ad Quir.

row.cell: If you do ought alone.
Si tecum agas quid, Cic. Off. 1.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI. Of the Particle Never.
div.p: 1. NEver) when it is put to ſignifie at no time, is made by I. nunquam or unquam, with ſome negative particle: as

cell.hi: I never [or at no time] thought on't before.

row.cell: Mihi ante hoc tempus nunquam in mentem venit.

cell.hi: I am ſo troubled, as never [or at no time] any man was.

row.cell: Ità ſum afflictus, ut nemo unquam, Cic.

div.p: ¶ Nunquam eoſdem teſtes pertimeſcet, Cic. Nihil cuiquam fuit unquam jucundìus, Cic. Nemo is unquam fuit, Cic. Nihil vidi unquam, quod minus explicari poſſet, Cic. Att. 7. Ep. 12. Neque potuiſſe eum unquam me ab hac expellere, Ter.
2. (Never) when it is put to ſignifie no, or not, is made by II. nullus or unus with ſome negative particle: as

cell.hi: There is never [no or not] a day almoſt, but he comes.

row.cell: Dies ferè nullus eſl, quin veniat, Cic.

cell.hi: He gave him never [no or not] a word.

row.cell: Ne unum quidem verbum reſpondit.

div.p: ¶ Nunquam unum intermittit diem, quin ſemper veniat, Ter. De excluſione verbum nullum, Ter. Eun. 1. 2. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Matth. 27. 14. Ne una quidem navis amiſſa eſt, Flor. 3. 6.
3. (Never) being a note of Intenſion, is to be rendered by III. the Superlative degree of the Adjective, or Adverb following it, or by ſome cquipellent phraſe: as

cell.hi: Though he be never ſo rich, yet he is not content.

row.cell: Etiamſi ditiſſimus [vel Craſſo ditior) fuerit, ſorte tamen ſuâ contentus non eſt.

cell.hi: Let him write never ſo well yet—

row.cell: Scripſerit vel optimè, tamen—

div.p: ¶ Sed quanti quanti [be the price never ſo great] bene emitur, quod neceſſe eſt, Cic. Verum ſi cognata eſt maxime [never ſo much of kin] Ter.

cell.hi: Never but once.

row.cell: Semel tantùm

cell.hi: Never the
more.

row.cell: Nihilo
plus. magìs.

cell.hi: better

row.cell: melior.

cell.hi: leſſe.

row.cell: minùs. ſecius.

cell.hi: ſooner

row.cell: citiùs or ocyùs.

div.p:
¶ * Exprobrantibus Conſulibus nihilo plus ſanitatis in c • riâ, quam in foro eſſe, Liv. Ea ſumitis, quibus conceſſis nihilo magìs efficitis, quod vultis, Cic. 2. de Div.
Nihilominus Helvetii id facere conantur, Caeſ. Nihilo beatior Jupiter, quàm Epicurus, demptâ eternitate, Cic. 2. de Fin. Nihilo ſecius obſequioſus fuiſti, Plaut.

cell.hi: Never at all.

row.cell: Ad Graecas Calendas.

cell.hi: Would I might never live, if I know.

row.cell: Ne vivam, ſi ſcio.

cell.hi: Never teach me—

row.cell: Ne me doce—

cell.hi: Never think to—

row.cell: Cave putes.
Noli putare.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. Of the Particle No.
div.p: 1. NO) without a Subſtantive, in Interrogative, Deliberative, I. and Negative, is made by ne, or non; in Negative, by non or minime, &c. as

cell.hi: I ask whether he could look for his part or no?

row.cell: Quaero potueritne partem ſuam quaerere, necne? Cic.

cell.hi: But whether is this he that I am ſeeking of, or no?

row.cell: Sed iſne eſt quem quaero, annon? Ter.

cell.hi: Should I return? no, though ſhe ſhould intreat me.

row.cell: Redeam? non, ſi me obſecret, Ter.

cell.hi: Would you have them let go then? No.

row.cell: Placet igitur eos dimitti? Minime.

div.p: ¶ Conſultant, ad vitae commoditatem—conducat id necne, de quo deliberant, Cic. 1. Off. 3. Non tali auxilio, nec defenſoribus iſtis Tempus eget: non ſi ipſe meus nunc afforet Hector, Virg. Aen. 2.
2. (No) With a Subſtantive, is made by * nemo, * nullus, II. non, nihil, with a Genitive caſe, or by quis and ullus with ſome negative Particle: as

cell.hi: Whom no man would have to be his clients—

row.cell: Quos clientes nemo habere velit—Cic.

cell.hi: You ſhall receive no denial.

row.cell: Nullam patiere repulſam.

cell.hi: No man almoſt did bid this man to his houſe.

row.cell: Domum ſuam iſtum non fere quiſquam vocabat, Cic.

cell.hi: Seeing he ſhall have no harm by telling it.

row.cell: Cum illi nihil pericli ex indicio ſiet, Ter. Heaut. 3. 1.

cell.hi: See that no wrong be done me.

row.cell: Efficias nequid mihi fiat injuriae—Cic. Fam. 15. 12.

cell.hi: I will take no wrong.

row.cell: Nolo ullam pati injuriam.

cell.hi: I would refuſe no pains.

row.cell: Non eſt labor ullus, quem detrectem.

div.p:
¶ * Nullus ac Nemo hoc inter ſe differunt, quòd illud generaliter ad omnia, hoc propriè ad homines tantùm refertur, Saturn. li. 5. cap. 30. Nemo tam improbus inveniri poterit, Cic. Nemo vir bonus cuiquam invidet, Plaut. Nemo enim orator tam multa ſcripſit, Cic. Tuorum erga me meritorum nulla unquam delebit oblivio, Cic. F. 2. 1. Propterea quod iter haberent nullum aliud, Caeſ. Com. 1. Non parvam rem quaeris, A. Gell. Non ego ſum claſſi ſarcina magna tuae, Ov. Ep. 3. Prandium abſtemium, in quo nihil vini potatur, Caninum dicitur, A. Gell. 13. 29. Nihil novi jamdiu ad nos afferebatur, Cic. In Pamphilo nihil ſit morae, Ter. Juſtitiae primum munus eſt, ut ne cui quis noceat, Cic. Off. 1. His ne quam patiare injuriam fieri, à te peto, Cic. l. 11. Ep. 19. Sophocl in Ajace,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Nihil opus eſt haec lugere fruſtra, Cic. ad Att. 1. Ep. 4. Accidit ut contentione nihil opus eſſet.

cell.hi: To no end or purpoſe.

row.cell: Necquicquam.
Fruſtra. Incaſſum.

cell.hi: He is no where to be found

row.cell: Nuſquam loci invenitur.

cell.hi: No marvel.

row.cell: Nec mirum, Cic. pro Quinr.
Minime mirnm.

cell.hi: I make no queſtion, but—

row.cell: Non [nihil] dubito, quin—

cell.hi: There is no cauſe why—

row.cell: Non
eſt
cur-
Nihil
quod—

div.p: ¶ Cauſa cur mentiretur non erat. Cic. pro Quint. Non eſt, quod te, ad hunc locum reſpiciens metiaris, Sen. Ep. 43.

cell.hi: To ſay no worſe.

row.cell: Ut
Molliſſimè
dicam.
Leviſſimè

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII. Of the Particle Not.
div.p: 1. NOt) before as, being the ſame in ſenſe with otherwiſe I. than, is made by aliter ac, or ſecus quam: as

cell.hi: May I periſh, if I write not as [or otherwiſe than] I think.

row.cell: Ne ſim ſalvus, ſi aliter ſcribo ac ſentio, Cic.

cell.hi: I am not as [or otherwiſe than] I would be.

row.cell: Secus ſum, quàm vellem.

div.p: ¶ Aliter atque oſtenderam ſacio, Cic. Si tu illam attigeris ſecus, quam dignum eſt, Ter. Phorm. Aliter de illis, ac de nobis judicamus, Cic. 1. Off. 12. Secus habui illam, ac ſi ex me eſſet nata, Ter. Hecyr. 2. 3.—Dixi ſecùs, ac ſentiebam, Cic. 2. de Oratore. Nunquam ſecus habui illam ac ſi ex me eſſet nata, Ter. Hecyr. Si tu illam attigeris ſecus quam dignum eſt liberam, T. Phorm. Pareus de Partic. L. L. p. 410, 411.
2. (Not) With a Verb, is made by nec, neque, non, haud, II. nihil, or minus, placed before the Verb: as

cell.hi: Bibulus's letters were not come yet.

row.cell: Nec dum Bibuli erant allatae literae, Cic.

cell.hi: For I cannot deny this.

row.cell: Neque enim hoc negare poſſum, Cic.

cell.hi: They doubt not, but—

row.cell: Illi non dubitant, quin—

cell.hi: I know not, whether—

row.cell: Haud ſcio, an—

cell.hi: I perceive not what thou intendeſt.

row.cell: Ego, quid agas, nihil intelligo, Ter.

cell.hi: Sometimes thoſe things fall not out, which have been foretold.

row.cell: Nonnunquam quae praedicta ſunt, minus eveniunt.

div.p: ¶ Nolo, idem valet, quod non volo. Nec enim illa prima vera eſt, Cic. de Am. Neque enim ſunt iſti audiendi, qui—Cic. de Am. Non tam mihi moleſtum fuit, Cic. Haud impune feres, Ovid. Met. 2. Haud faciam, Ter. Si Parthi vos nihil calfaciunt, Cic. Fam. 8. 9. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Si minus ſuccedet, Cic. Minùs multi cauſâ cadent, Cic. Fam. 17. Ep. 14. Minus facile poſſunt, Caeſ. Si id mihi minus contingat, Cic. 2. de Oratore.
3. (Not) in praying, forbidding, and bewaring, is made by III. ne, or cave with a Subjuuctive, or noli with an Infinitive mood: as

cell.hi: I deſire you not to ask that of me.

row.cell: Peto à te, ne id à me quaeras, Cic.

cell.hi: Do not intreat me.

row.cell: Ne me obſecra, Ter.

cell.hi: Do not think that any letters were ever more welcome than yours.

row.cell: Cave putes ullas literas unquam gratiores quam tuas fuiſſe, Cic.

cell.hi: Do not think that I had rather have had any thing, than—

row.cell: Noli putare me quicquam maluiſſe, quam—Cic.

cell.hi: We muſt beware, that the puniſhment be not greater then the fault.

row.cell: Cavendum eſt, ne major poena, quam culpa ſit, Cic. Off.

div.p:
¶ Hoc te primùm rogo, ne contrahas, ac demittas animum, Cic. ad Qu. Fr. 2. 1. Peto à te, ne me putes oblivione tui rariùs ad te ſcribere, quam ſolebam, Cic. Fam. 6. 2. Ne ſperne meae praeſagia linguae, Ovid. Met. 2. 551. Ne hunc ornatum vos meum admiremini, Plaut. Ne me moneatis, memini ego officium meum, Plaut. Cave ſi me ames, exiſtimes me—Cic. Cave ſis audiam ego iſtuc poſthac ex te, Plaut. Stich. A. 1. S. 1. Noli putare amabiliora fieri poſſe, Cic. ad Att. 12. 10. Nolite exiſtimare eos, Cic.
Cavendum eſt, ne aſſentatoribus patefaciamus aures, Cic. Off. 1.
4. (Not) In Interrogations is made by non, or ne: as IV.

cell.hi: Speak I not? Watch I not?

row.cell: Non loquor? Non vigilo?

cell.hi: Did I not ſay it would fall out ſo?

row.cell: Annon dixi hoc eſſe futurum? Ter.

cell.hi: Ought I not to have known of it before?

row.cell: Nónne oportuit praeſcîſſe me antea?

div.p: ¶ Eſtne invocatum, annon eſt? Plaut. Captiv. 1. Sc. 1. Dixin' hoc fore?

row.cell: Not without cauſe.
Nec injuriâ.
He cometh not at all.
Is nullus venit.
Not that I know of.
Non quod ſciam.
Ne literae quidem meae impediuntur, Cic. 6. Ep. 19. Not he himſelf could have perſwaded me.
Ne ipſe quidem mihi perſuaſiſſet, Cic.

div.p: ¶ Non modò C. Marius qui erat inimicus, ſed nè is quidem qui ſecutus eſt—Cic. ad Quir.

row.cell: That I ſay not.
Ne dicam—
Not ſo of • as I uſed.
Rariùs, quam ſolebam, Cic.

cell.hi: I fear I cannot.

row.cell: Vereor, ut poſſim, Cic.

div.p: ¶ Vereor, ut ſatìs diligenter actum in Senatu ſit de meis literis, Cic. ad Att. 6. 4.
Not but—See But, Chap. 13. Rule 6, 7.
Not ſo much as—Chap. Phr.
(Not) after If: See If, Chap. 19, Rule 3, & 4.
(Not) after And: See And, Chap. 6. Rule 2.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX. Of Nounes repeated with a Prepoſition betwixt them.
div.p: WHen a Noun is repeated together with a Prepoſition, it is generally made in Latine by an Adverb: as

cell.hi: One by one.

row.cell: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Sigillatim.

cell.hi: Man by man.

row.cell: Viritim.

cell.hi: From door to door.

row.cell: Oſtiatim.

cell.hi: Word for word.

row.cell: Verbatim.

cell.hi: By litle and litle.

row.cell: Paulatim. [Pedentim.]

cell.hi: Face to face.

row.cell: * Coram.

div.p: 1 Cor. 13. 12. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Facie ad faciem. 2 Joh. 12. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Os ad os.
Quo mihi cùm coràm id non licet, nihil eſt jucundius, Cic. Att. 7. 15.

cell.hi: He tranſlated it word for word.

row.cell: Verbum de verbo expreſſum extulit, Ter.

cell.hi: To fight hand to hand.

row.cell: Manum conſerere.
Comminus pugnare.

div.p: ¶ Illum ego locum totidem verbis à Dicaearcho tranſtuli, Cic. Att. l. 6. Vide Turſell. cap. 208. obſ. 5.

cell.hi: To wait day after day.

row.cell: Diem de die expectare, Cic. ad Att. l. 7. Cum is diem de die differret, Liv. Dec. 3. l. 5.

div.head: CHAP. XXX. Of the Particle Of.
div.p: 1. OF) between two Subſtantives coming immediately together, I. is ſigne of a Genitive caſe: but if an Adjective denoting ſome quality in a perſon, orthing, be joyned to the latter Subſtantive, that Subſtantive is ſometimes of the *Genitive, and ſometimes of the* Ablative caſe: as

cell.hi: The love of money encreaſeth as much as the money it ſelf.

row.cell: Creſcit amor nummi, quantùm ipſa pecunia creſcit, Juven.

cell.hi: A boy of an honeſt look.

row.cell: Ingenui vultûs puer, Juven.

cell.hi: A man of no credit.

row.cell: Vir nullâ fide.

cell.hi: Be of good chear.

row.cell: Bono animo eſto, Ter. Ad.

div.p: ¶ Mirum me tenet urbis deſiderium, Cic. Quem neque fortunae temeritas, neque inimicorum labefactaret injuria, Cic. Earum, quae ſuperſunt, curam agis, Curt. l. 4.

* Neque enim indifferenter in alterutro caſu efferuntur, Farn. Syſt. Gram, pag. 56. Non multi cibi hoſpitem accipies, ſed multi joci, Cic. Ep. ult. l. 9. Formâ praeſtante puellae, Ovid. Ep. 3. Sunt mihi bis ſeptem praeſtanti corpore nymphae, Virg. Aen. 1. Homo antiquâ virtute ac fide, Ter. Adel. Act. 3. Sc. 3. Tam nulli conſilii ſum, Ter. And. A. 3. Sc. ult. Cibi erat minimi ac fere vulgaris, Suet. in Aug. Quam tenui fuit, aut nullâ potiùs valetudine, Ter. Ad. Ipſe eſt ingenio bono, Ter. And. Non ità ſunt diſſimili argumento, Ter. And.

2. (Of) before the Engliſh of the Participle II. of the Preſent Tenſe, coming after certain Spes, tempus, cauſa, occaſio, opportunit as, modus, ratio, conſuetudo &c. Subſtantives, or after Adjctives governing a Genitive caſe, is generally a ſigne of a Gerund in di: as

cell.hi: This is my way of living.

row.cell: Haec eſt ratio mea vivendi.

cell.hi: Deſtrous of ſeeing.

row.cell: Cupidus viſendi.

div.p: ¶ Quo facilius nos incenſos ſtudio dicendi à doctrinâ deterrerent, Cic. de Orat. l. 2. Finem dicendi faciam, Cic. Amor urget habendi, Virg. Geor. 4. Aliquod fuit principium generandi animalium, Varro de R R. l. 2. c. 1. Efficiet facilè hanc viam componendi, Cic. Reliquorum ſiderum quae cauſa collocandi fuerit, Cic. de Ʋniverſ. Novarum qui ſpectandi faciunt copiam, Ter. in Prol. Heaut. Homines bellandi cupidi, Caeſ. 1. bell. Gall.
3. (Of) before a Subſtantive ſignifying the matter whereof III. a thing is made, is uſually tranſlated by è, de, or ex; *yet. ſometimes the Subſtantive is rendered by an Adjective material: as

cell.hi: A cup of gold.

row.cell: Calix ex auro, [or Calix aureus.]

cell.hi: A bed of ſoft fleggs.

row.cell: Torus de mollibus ulvis.

div.p: ¶ * Nomen materiae, apud Poet as, vel in Genitive, vel in Ablativo cum Praepoſitione, nonnunquam etiam ſine Praepoſitione uſurpatur, Ovid. Met. 2. 683. Baculus ſilveſtris olivae, Ovid. Met. 2. 555. Clauſerat Actaeo textâ de vimine ciſtâ, Ovid. Met. 8. 657. In medio torus eſt de mollibns ulvis Impoſitus lecto ſpondâ pedibuſque ſalignis, Id. Met. 2. 684. Septenis fiſtula cannis, Id. Met. 1. v. 176. Graciles ex aere catenas Elimat. Vas è gemmâ praegrandi, Cic. Ver. 6. Fabrè factum è ferro, Plaut. Rud. E ſaxo ſculptus, è robore dolatus, Cic. Acad. l. 4. A pud Pareum de Partic. p. 608. Simulacrum ex aere, Cic. Verr. 6. Clypeus unus ex auro totus, Liv. apud Parei Comde Partic. p. 609.
4. (Of) before mine, thine, ours, and yours, is a ſigne that IV the Latine Pronouns are to agree with the foregoing Subſtantive: as

cell.hi: I heard the orher day of a friend of mine.

row.cell: Accepl dudum à quodam familiari meo.

cell.hi: That good will of thine towards me.

row.cell: Tuum iſtud erga me ſtudium.

cell.hi: A neighbour of ours.

row.cell: Vicinus quidam noſter.

cell.hi: This houſe of yours is like to fall.

row.cell: Veſtra haec domus eſt ruitura.

div.p: But when his or hers, its or theirs followes of, the Latine Pronouns may then be put in the Genitive caſe: as

cell.hi: This book of his.

row.cell: Hic illius codex, Vide cap. 17.

div.p: ¶ Multis meis, & firmis praeſidiis obſeſſus, Cic. Cat. 1. Quamdiu nos furor iſte tuus eludet? Cic. Cat. 1. Et tu occupatus in meo fortaſſe aliquo negotio, Cic. Att. 12. 6. Nam me haec tua Platanus admonuit, Cic. 1. de Orat. Eſt ille Cliniae ſervus tardiuſculus, idcirco huic noſtro tradita eſt provincia, Ter. Heaut. Act. 3. Sc. 2.

5. (Of) After Adjectives ſignifying deſire, knowledge, V carefulneſſe, remembrance, fearfulneſſe, and their contraries; likewiſe after the Engliſh of Verbals in ax, and Participials of the Preſent and Preterperfect tenſe, is ſigne of a Genitive caſe: as

cell.hi: Deſtrous of gold.

row.cell: Cupidus auri.

cell.hi: Expert of warfare.

row.cell: Peritus belli,

cell.hi: Ignorant of all things.

row.cell: Ignarus omnium.

cell.hi: Careful of what is to come.

row.cell: Futuri anxius.

cell.hi: Careleſſe of what ſhall be hereafter.

row.cell: Futuri ſecurus.

cell.hi: Mindful of that which is paſt.

row.cell: Memor praeteriti.

cell.hi: Do you think me ſo forgetful of my conſtancy, ſo mindleſſe of what things I performed?

row.cell: Adcóne vobis oblitus conſtantiae meae, adeò immemor rerum à me geſtarum eſſe videor? Cic.

cell.hi: Fearful of the light.

row.cell: Timidus lucis.

cell.hi: A minde fearleſſe of death.

row.cell: Mens interrita lethi, Ovid.

cell.hi: Capable of a noble minde.

row.cell: Altae capax mentis.

cell.hi: Bold of heart.

row.cell: Fidens animi.

cell.hi: Unſkilful of the ball.

row.cell: Indoctus pilae.

div.p:
¶ Quod cum cupidum rerum novatum, cupidum imperii cognoverat, Caeſ. 5. bell. Gall. Eſt natura hominum novitatis avida, Plin.
Praeter laudem nullius avaris, Hor. de Art. Poet. Largus opum. Aen. 11. Munificus laudis, ſed non es prodigus auri, Claud. Sic Graeci 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Juris, literarum, & antiquitatum peritus, Cic. in Bruto.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Thucyd. Imprudens harum rerum ignaruſque omnium, Ter. Eun. Neſcia mens hominum fati ſortiſque futurae, Virg.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Ariſtot. Calamitoſus eſt animus futuri anxius; & ante miſerias miſer, Sen. Ep. 98. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Xenoph. Sapiens vivit praeſentibus laetus, futuri ſecurus, Sen. de Vit. beat. Nolim caeterarum rerum re ſocordem, Ter. Adelph. Vetera extollimus, recentium incurioſi, Tac. l. 2. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lucian. Vive memor lethi, Perſ. 5. Sat.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Hom. Nolo me credi eſſe immemorem viri, Plaut. Stich. A. 1. Sc. 1. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Syneſ. Cautus nimiùm timiduſque procellae, Hor. de Art. Poet. Impavidus ſomni ſervat pecus, Sil. l. 7. Propoſiti tenax, Hor. 3. l. 3. Od. Alieni oppetens, ſui profuſus, Sal. Catil. Metuens alterius viri, Hor. 3. l. 24. Od. Servantiſſimus aequi, Virg Aen. 2.
6. (Of) after all Partitives and Adjectives put partitively, VI. Comparatives, Superlatives, Interrogatives, and Numerals, is ſigne of a Genitive * caſe: as

cell.hi: Whom I know ſhal be married to ſome of his ſervants.

row.cell: Quam ſeio alicui ſervorum ejus nupturam, Curt.

cell.hi: Many of thoſe trees were ſet with my own hand.

row.cell: Multae iſtarum arborum memanu ſunt ſatae, Cic.

cell.hi: The elder of you.

row.cell: Major veſtiûm.

cell.hi: The moſt elegant of all the Philoſophers.

row.cell: Elegantiſſimus omnium Philoſophorum, Cic. Tuſc. 5.

cell.hi: Which of us think'ſt thou is ignorant of—

row.cell: Quem noſtiûm ignorare arbitraris? Cic. Cat. 1.

cell.hi: The eighth of the wiſe men.

row.cell: Sapientum octavus, Hor. Sal. 3. l. 2.

div.p:
¶ Quorum alter
te ſcientiâ augere poteſt, Cic. Off. 1. Nihil horum—Mart. l. 3. Ep. 72. Quiſquis fuit ille Deorum, Ovid. Met. 1. Divûm promittere nemo Auderet, Virg. Domus eſt, quae nulli villarum mearum cedat, Cic. 6. Ep. 19. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Plat.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Luc. 13. 15. Cum pancis amicorum ad Leonatum pervenit, Curt. O major juvenum—Hor. Horum omnium fortiſſimi ſunt Belgae, Caeſ. de bell. Gall. 1. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , 1 Cor. 15. 9. Quis omnium doctior? Cic. Quotuſquiſque Philoſophorum invenitur? Cic. Octoginta Macedonum interfecerunt, Curt. 8. Infice tale tuâ naturum Cecropis unam, Ov. Met. 2. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Luc. 5. 3. Pompei meorū prime ſodaliū, Hor. l. 2. Od. 7. Unus multorum, Hor. l. 1. S. 9. * This Genitive is ſomtimes varied by a Prepoſition: as, Eſt Deus è vobis alter, Ov. Solus de ſuperis, Ov. Unus è Stoicis, Cic. l. 2. de Divin. Is enim unus fuit de magiſtratibus defenſor ſalut is meae, Cic. pro Planco. Ex duabus tuis prior, Cic. ad Alt. l. 16. Ep. 13. In teſtamento Ptolemaei patris haeredes erant ſcripti. Ex duobus filiis major, & ex duabus, quae aetate antecedebat, Caeſ. l. 3. bel. Civil. Ego ſum infelicior ex duobus parentibus, Quint. Dec. 19.
7. (Of) After the Engliſh of opus † or uſus [ſignifying need] VII dignus, indignus, natus, ſatus, cretus, ortus, editus, &c. is ſigne of an Ablative † caſe: as

cell.hi: You have no need of a wiſe.

row.cell: Non opus eſt tibi conjuge, Ov.

cell.hi: I have need of your help.

row.cell: Uſus eſt tuâ mihi operâ.

cell.hi: Worthy of praiſe.

row.cell: Laude dignus.

div.p:
¶ Nil opus eſt bello, Ovid. Am. 1. 3. Non uſus facto eſt mihi, Ter. Pecuniam, quâ ſibi nihil eſſet uſus non accepit, Gel. Provenient cauſâ carmina digna ſuâ, Ovid. Am. 1. 3. Indignum ſapientis gravitate, Cic. Non tu natus equo, Ovid. Am. 2. 3. Laerte ſatus, Ovid. Ep. 3. Quo ſanguine cretus, Ovid. Venus orta mari—Maecenas atavis edite regibus, Hor. Et jam puer Arcas fuerat de pellice natus, Ov. Plato ait neminem regem non ex ſervis eſſe oriundum, Sen. Ep. 44. Bona bonis prognata parentibus, Ter. † Dixit tamen Ovidius, l. 2. de Arte
Amandi,—Hic erit artis opus. Et Plancus apud Cic. l. 10. Ep. 8. Nagni laboris opus ſuit.
8. (Of) After Adjectives of fulneſs, or emptineſs, is ſigne VIII either of a Genitive or Ablative caſe: as

cell.hi: A City full of Watlike ſtores.

row.cell: Apparatu bellico plena urbs, Liv.

cell.hi: Full of courteſſe.

row.cell: Officii plenus, Cic.

cell.hi: A body bold of blood and life.

row.cell: Sanguinis atque animae corpus inane, Ov.

cell.hi: A letter bold of any uſeful or relightful matter.

row.cell: Epiſtola inanis aliquâ re utili & ſuavi.

div.p: ¶ Vox plena terroris, Ovid. Plenus ſaevitiae, Claud. Sunt enim rationes & orationis expertes, Cic. 1. Off. 20. Opinio nobis fuit [eum] omnino omnis eruditionis expertem, atque ignarum fuiſſe, Cic. de Oratore 2. Vacui curâ atque labore, Cic. de Oratore 2.
9. (Of) After Verbs of accuſing, Condemning, warning, or IX. abſolving, is ſigne of a Genitive or Ablative caſe, with [and ſometimes without] a Prepoſition: as

cell.hi: He accuſeth another man of riſhoneſty.

row.cell: Alterum incuſat probri.

cell.hi: He grievouſly accuſed his wife of unchaſtity.

row.cell: Uxorem de pudicitiâ graviter accuſavit.

cell.hi: He condemns his ſon in law of wickedneſſe.

row.cell: Sceleris condemnat generum ſaum.

cell.hi: I will condemn thee of the ſame crime.

row.cell: Eodem ego te crimine condemnabo.

cell.hi: Admoniſh him of his former fortune.

row.cell: Admoneto illum priſtinae fortunae.

cell.hi: I thought you were to be admoniſhed of that matter.

row.cell: Putavi eâ de re admonendum eſſete.

cell.hi: He is acquitted of theft.

row.cell: Furti [or furto] abſolutus eſt.

div.p:
¶ Aliquot matronas a pud populum probri accusâ runt, Liv. 5. bell. Punic. Ut me accuſare de epiſtolarum negligentiâ poſſis, Cic. ad Att. 1.
Ego cert is propriiſque criminibus accuſabo, Cic. in Verr. 3. Arguitur lentae crimine avaritiae, Mart. l. 11. Ep. 80. Gracchus ejuſdem criminis abſolvitur, Tac. l. 4. Malè adminiſtratae provinciae aliorumque criminum urgebatur. Tac. l. 5. Apud quos cùm potentiſſimi qui
que rei ejus ipſius criminis poſtularemtur. Juſtin. l. 9. Otia delectent, admoneantque mei, Ov. Gramaticos ſui officii commonemus. Quint. l. 1. c. 5. Cùm ipſe te veteris amicitiae commonefaceret, commotus es. Cic. ad Heren. De altero ei me purgavi, Cic. ad Att. l. 10.
